\begin{lemma}
\label{lemma-base-change-representable}
Let $FORMULA$ be a category.
Let $FORMULA$ be representable.
Let $FORMULA$ be a morphism of $FORMULA$.
Then the morphism $FORMULA$ is representable also.
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
Let $FORMULA$ be a morphism. The fibre product
$FORMULA$ is supposed to represent the
functor
\begin{eqnarray*}
w & \mapsto & h_{x'}(w)\times_{h_{y'}(w)} h_z(w) \\
& = & (h_x(w) \times_{h_y(w)} h_{y'}(w)) \times_{h_{y'}(w)} h_z(w) \\
& = & h_x(w) \times_{h_y(w)} h_z(w)
\end{eqnarray*}
which is representable by assumption.
\end{proof}

\begin{lemma}
\label{lemma-Noetherian-goes-to-spectral}
Let $FORMULA$ be a topological space and let $FORMULA$ be the universal
map from $FORMULA$ to a sober topological space, see
Lemma \ref{lemma-make-sober}.
\begin{enumerate}
\item If $FORMULA$ is quasi-compact, so is $FORMULA$.
\item If $FORMULA$ is quasi-compact, has a basis of quasi-compact opens,
and the intersection of two quasi-compact opens is quasi-compact, then
$FORMULA$ is spectral.
\item If $FORMULA$ is Noetherian, then $FORMULA$ is a Noetherian spectral space.
\end{enumerate}
\end{lemma}

\noindent
What is crucial in the proof above is that the partially ordered set of open
neighbourhoods is a directed set (Categories, Definition
\ref{categories-definition-directed-set}). Namely, the coproduct
of two abelian groups $FORMULA$ is the direct sum $FORMULA$, whereas
the coproduct in the category of sets is the disjoint
union $FORMULA$, showing that colimits in the category
of abelian groups do not agree with colimits in the
category of sets in general.

Namely, observe that $FORMULA$
is continuous as every
$FORMULA$-covering is a $FORMULA$-covering. Thus the functor
$FORMULA$ is the identity functor on underlying
presheaves. Hence the left adjoint $FORMULA$
of $FORMULA$ sends a $FORMULA$-sheaf $FORMULA$
to the $FORMULA$-sheafification of $FORMULA$ (by the
universal property of sheafification).
Finite limits of $FORMULA$-sheaves agree with finite limits
of presheaves (Lemma \ref{lemma-limit-sheaf}) and $FORMULA$-sheafification
commutes with finite limits (Lemma \ref{lemma-sheafification-exact}).
Thus $FORMULA$ is left exact. Since $FORMULA$
is a left adjoint it is also right exact
(Categories, Lemma \ref{categories-lemma-exact-adjoint}).
Thus $FORMULA$ is exact and we have checked all the
conditions of Definition \ref{definition-morphism-sites}.
\end{example}

\section{Introduction}
\label{section-introduction}
\noindent
In this chapter, we shall discuss the theory of fields. Recall that a
{\it field} is a ring in which all nonzero elements are invertible.
Equivalently, the only two ideals of a field are $FORMULA$ and $FORMULA$
since any nonzero element is a unit. Consequently fields will be the
simplest cases of much of the theory developed later.
\medskip\noindent
The theory of field extensions has a different feel from standard commutative
algebra since, for instance, any morphism of fields is injective. Nonetheless,
it turns out that questions involving rings can often be reduced to questions
about fields. For instance, any domain can be embedded in a field
(its quotient field), and any {\it local ring} (that is, a ring with a unique
TEXT

see Lemma \ref{lemma-tensor-products-commute-with-limits}.
This property is usually expressed by saying
that {\it $FORMULA$ commutes with colimits}.
Another often used result is that if $FORMULA$
is an exact sequence and if $FORMULA$ is any $FORMULA$-module, then
$$FORMULA$$
is still exact, see Lemma \ref{lemma-tensor-product-exact}.
Both of these properties tell us that the functor
$FORMULA$ {\it is right exact}.
See Categories, Section \ref{categories-section-exact-functor}
and Homology, Section \ref{homology-section-functors}.
An $FORMULA$-module $FORMULA$ is flat if $FORMULA$ is also left exact,
i.e., if it is exact. Here is the precise definition.

\noindent
In other words it is the supremum of the lengths of chains
of submodules. There is an obvious notion of when a chain
of submodules is a refinement of another. This gives a
partial ordering on the collection of all chains of submodules,
with the smallest chain having the shape $FORMULA$
if $FORMULA$ is not zero.
We note the obvious fact that if the length of
$FORMULA$ is finite, then every chain can be refined to a
maximal chain. But it is not as obvious that all maximal
chains have the same length (as we will see later).
\begin{lemma}
\label{lemma-finite-length-finite}
\begin{slogan}
Modules of finite length are finite.
\end{slogan}
Let $FORMULA$ be a ring.
Let $FORMULA$ be an $FORMULA$-module.
If $FORMULA$ then $FORMULA$ is a finite $FORMULA$-module.
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
Omitted.

\section{Artinian rings}
\label{section-artinian}
\noindent
Artinian rings, and especially local Artinian rings,
play an important role in algebraic geometry, for example
in deformation theory.
\begin{definition}
\label{definition-artinian}
A ring $FORMULA$ is {\it Artinian} if it satisfies the
descending chain condition for ideals.
\end{definition}
\begin{lemma}
\label{lemma-finite-dimensional-algebra}
Suppose $FORMULA$ is a finite dimensional algebra over a field.
Then $FORMULA$ is Artinian.
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
The descending chain condition for ideals obviously holds.
\end{proof}
\begin{lemma}
\label{lemma-artinian-finite-nr-max}
If $FORMULA$ is Artinian then $FORMULA$ has only finitely many maximal ideals.
\end{lemma}

\begin{definition}
\label{definition-weakly-associated}
Let $FORMULA$ be a ring. Let $FORMULA$ be an $FORMULA$-module.
A prime $FORMULA$ of $FORMULA$ is {\it weakly associated} to $FORMULA$
if there exists an element $FORMULA$ such that $FORMULA$ is minimal
among the prime ideals containing the annihilator
$FORMULA$.
The set of all such primes is denoted $FORMULA$
or $FORMULA$.
\end{definition}
\noindent
Thus an associated prime is a weakly associated prime.
Here is a characterization in terms of the localization at the prime.

\section{Formally \'etale maps}
\label{section-formally-etale}
\begin{definition}
\label{definition-formally-etale}
Let $FORMULA$ be a ring map.
We say $FORMULA$ is {\it formally \'etale over $FORMULA$} if for every
commutative solid diagram
$$
 \xymatrix{}
TEXT \ar[r] } TEXT  
TEXT \ar[r] } TEXTTEXT \ar[u]}
TEXT
$$
where $FORMULA$ is an ideal of square zero, there exists
a unique dotted arrow making the diagram commute.
\end{definition}
\noindent
Clearly a ring map is formally \'etale if and only if
it is both formally smooth and formally unramified.
\begin{lemma}
\label{lemma-formally-etale-etale}
Let $FORMULA$ be a ring map of finite presentation.
The following are equivalent:
\begin{enumerate}
\item $FORMULA$ is formally \'etale,
\item $FORMULA$ is \'etale.
\end{enumerate}
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
Assume that $FORMULA$ is formally \'etale.
Then $FORMULA$ is smooth by
Proposition \ref{proposition-smooth-formally-smooth}.
By Lemma \ref{lemma-characterize-formally-unramified}
we have $FORMULA$.
Hence $FORMULA$ is \'etale by definition.
\medskip\noindent
Assume that $FORMULA$ is \'etale.
Then $FORMULA$ is formally smooth by
Proposition \ref{proposition-smooth-formally-smooth}.
By Lemma \ref{lemma-characterize-formally-unramified}
it is formally unramified. Hence $FORMULA$ is formally \'etale.
 \end{proof}
